GENERAL OFFICE
ALAMEDA

DISTRICT TRAFFIC OFFICI
MANILA HOTEL
MANILA, t.I
Baguio,
PoI.
Oot. 11, 1937
Letter No. B-23-37.
Pan American Airways Company
New York.
Attention Mr. Morgan:
Dear Mr. Morgan:
I was very much interested in your letter of September 22nd and
Your ese hostilities would
analysis of the developments which led up to the opening
of the Sino-
seem to indicate that a student of Chinese af-
fairs far removed
from the daily gossip and rumors of the street is
probab-
ly in a better position to judge the value of the forces
than one who is,
as you state, so close to the trees that he
can't see the woods.
However
I do not entirely agree with you that China
"came out from under the desk
with a brass knuckle on either hand".
It is true that
China has been pre-
paring but that
preparation was no where near complete as evidenced by
fact that China
already running short of many
essential materials.
the
You
go on to say
that there is considerable talk in New York and elsewhere to
Chinese Government was
dragged into the war through
public opinion and inability to restrain the military leaders and masses
of the people any longer and then you go on to state
that in your opinion
this theory is unsound and point in support of your position to the ample
preparations
made
against a war with Japan.
am personally still of the opinion that Chiang Kai-shek was
not ready
and desired
to go to any ends rather than permit the starting
of hostilities which
might lead to his own overthrow and a complete de-
feat of China.
I believe he would have gladly worked out some compromise
for a
show of war in the North to be followed by definite concessions in-
cluding an autonomous
state in the Province of Hopei and probably north
Shantung.
Most
authorities agree that the actual starting of hostilities
in the
Shanghai
area was brought on by the Chinese rather than the Japanese
as
the latter had
been unusually conciliatory with respect to all incidents
in the Shanghai area.
In this connection I had a very interesting talk
with a man here who
is known to you as an outstanding military strategist.
He states that only
the results
justify the action of the Japanese in de-
fending
their position at Shanghai.
It was known that there were only
10,000 Japanese troops in the Shanghai area as
Chinese,
including the
against not less than 60,000
best troops
that General Chiang could put in the
field.
I told this party that a Chinese official informed me on the night
of August
14th
that
the Japanese would be pushed into the Whangpoo that
night
and
the same party repeated that statement on the 15th.
friend here
stated that there wes no excuse whatever for the Chinese not
completing
that objective and that if he had been in the position of the
Japanese Commander
he would have taken to the boats and left Shanghai
